Guidelines for Charactering "OAM" Guidelines for Characterizing "OAM"
draft-ietf-opsawg-oam-characterization-03 draft-ietf-opsawg-oam-characterization-03
Abstract Abstract
As the IETF continues to produce and standardize different As the IETF continues to produce and standardize different
Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (OAM) protocols and Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (OAM) protocols and
technologies, various qualifiers and modifiers are prepended to the technologies, various qualifiers and modifiers are prepended to the
OAM abbreviation. While, at first glance, the most used appear to be OAM abbreviation. While, at first glance, the most used appear to be
well understood, the same qualifier may be interpreted differently in well understood, the same qualifier may be interpreted differently in
different contexts. A case in point is the qualifiers "in-band" and different contexts. A case in point is the qualifiers "in-band" and
"out-of-band" which have their origins in the radio lexicon, and "out-of-band" which have their origins in the radio lexicon, and
which have been extrapolated into other communication networks. which have been extrapolated into other communication networks.
This document considers some common qualifiers and modifiers that are This document considers some common qualifiers and modifiers that are
prepended, within the context of packet networks, to the OAM prepended, within the context of packet networks, to the OAM
abbreviation and lays out guidelines for their use in future IETF abbreviation and lays out guidelines for their use in future IETF
work. work.
This document updates RFC 6291 by adding to the guidelines for the This document updates RFC 6291 by adding to the guidelines for the
use of the term "OAM". use of the term "OAM". It does not modify any other part of RFC
6291.

2. In-Band and Out-of-Band OAM 2. In-Band and Out-of-Band OAM
Historically, the terms "in-band" and "out-of-band" were used Historically, the terms "in-band" and "out-of-band" were used
extensively in radio communications as well as in telephony signaling extensively in radio communications as well as in telephony signaling
skipping to change at page 3, line 41 ¶ skipping to change at page 3, line 42 ¶
in-packet or on-path. in-packet or on-path.
Within the IETF, the terms "in-band" and "out-of-band" cannot be Within the IETF, the terms "in-band" and "out-of-band" cannot be
reliably understood consistently and unambiguously. Context-specific reliably understood consistently and unambiguously. Context-specific
redefinitions of these terms cannot be generalized and can be redefinitions of these terms cannot be generalized and can be
confused by participants from other contexts. More importantly, the confused by participants from other contexts. More importantly, the
terms are not self-defining to any further extent and cannot be terms are not self-defining to any further extent and cannot be
understood by someone exposed to them for the first time, since there understood by someone exposed to them for the first time, since there
is no "band" in IP. is no "band" in IP.
2.1. Terminology and Guidance
The guidance in this document is to avoid the terms "in-band" and The guidance in this document is to avoid the terms "in-band" and
"out-of-band", and instead find finer-granularity descriptive terms. "out-of-band" when refering to OAM, and instead find finer-
The definitions presented in this document are for use in all future granularity descriptive terms. The definitions presented in this
IETF documents that refer to OAM, and the terms "in-band OAM" and document are for use in all future IETF documents that refer to OAM,
"out-of-band OAM" are not to be used in future documents. and the terms "in-band OAM" and "out-of-band OAM" are not to be used
in future documents.
Path: OAM in relation to a path. Path OAM: OAM in relation to a path.
Path-Congruent OAM: Path-Congruent OAM:
The OAM information follows the exact same path as the observed The OAM information follows the exact same path as the observed
data traffic. This was sometimes referred to as "in-band". data traffic. This was sometimes referred to as "in-band".
Non-Path-Congruent OAM: Non-Path-Congruent OAM:
The OAM information does not follow the same path as the The OAM information does not follow the exact same path as the
observed data traffic. This was sometimes referred to as "out- observed data traffic. This was sometimes referred to as "out-
of-band". of-band".
[RFC6669] gives an example of "Path-Congruent OAM", and further [RFC6669], Section 2 fourth bullet, gives an example of "Path-
describes that the OAM Packets "share their fate with data Congruent OAM", and further describes that the OAM Packets "share
packets." their fate with data packets."
Packet: OAM in relation to a user data packet. Packet OAM: OAM in relation to a user data packet.
In-Packet OAM: In-Packet OAM:
The OAM information is carried in the packets that also carry The OAM information is carried in the packets that also carry
the data traffic. This was sometimes referred to as "in-band". the data traffic. This was sometimes referred to as "in-band".
Dedicated-Packet OAM: Dedicated-Packet OAM:
The OAM information is carried in its own OAM packets, separate The OAM information is carried in its own OAM packets, separate
from data traffic. This was sometimes referred to as "out-of- from data traffic. This was sometimes referred to as "out-of-
band". band".

packets, as for example QoS treatment. treatment of user data packets, as for example QoS treatment.
Equal-QoS-Treatment OAM: Equal-Forwarding-Treatment OAM:
The OAM packets receive the same QoS treatment as user data The OAM packets receive the same forwarding (e.g., QoS)
packets. This was sometimes referred to as "in-band". treatment as user data packets. This was sometimes referred to
as "in-band".
Different-QoS-Treatment OAM: Different-Forwarding-Treatment OAM:
The OAM packets receive different QoS treatment as user data The OAM packets receive different forwarding (e.g., QoS)
packets. This was sometimes referred to as "out-of-band". treatment as user data packets. This was sometimes referred to
as "out-of-band".
For a case of either "Non-Path-Congruent OAM" or "Different-QoS- For a case of either "Non-Path-Congruent OAM" or "Different-
Treatment OAM", [I-D.ietf-detnet-oam-framework] says "Out-of-band Forwarding-Treatment OAM", [RFC9551] says "Out-of-band OAM: an
OAM is an active OAM whose path through the DetNet domain is not active OAM method whose path through the DetNet domain may not be
topologically identical to the path of the monitored DetNet flow, topologically identical to the path of the monitored DetNet flow,
or its test packets receive different QoS and/or PREOF treatment, its test packets may receive different QoS and/or PREOF treatment,
or both." [I-D.ietf-raw-architecture] uses similar text. or both." [I-D.ietf-raw-architecture] uses similar text.
Combined: OAM in relation to multiple criteria. For example, in Combined OAM: OAM in relation to multiple criteria. For example, in
relation to both topological congruence and packet treatment. relation to both topological congruence and packet treatment.
[I-D.ietf-detnet-oam-framework] uses Combined OAM when it says [RFC9551] uses Combined OAM when it says "In-band OAM: an active
"In-band OAM is an active OAM that is in-band within the monitored OAM method that is in band within the monitored DetNet OAM domain
DetNet OAM domain when it traverses the same set of links and when it traverses the same set of links and interfaces receiving
interfaces receiving the same QoS and Packet Replication, the same QoS and Packet Replication, Elimination, and Ordering
Elimination, and Ordering Functions (PREOF) treatment as the Functions (PREOF) treatment as the monitored DetNet flow."

2.1. Historical Uses 2.2. Historical Uses
There are many examples of "in-band OAM" and "out-of-band OAM" in There are many examples of "in-band OAM" and "out-of-band OAM" in
published RFCs. While interpreting those, it is important to published RFCs. While interpreting those, it is important to
understand the semantics of what "band" is a proxy for, and to be understand the semantics of what "band" is a proxy for, and to be
more explicit if those documents are updated. This document does not more explicit if those documents are updated. This document does not
change the meaning of any terms in any prior RFCs. change the meaning of any terms in any prior RFCs.

or out-of-band", and "in-band (i.e., following the same data-plane or out-of-band", and "in-band (i.e., following the same data-plane
faith as PW data)". Hence, in that specific case, the term "band" faith as PW data)". Hence, in that specific case, the term "band"

[RFC7799] provides clear definitions for active and passive [RFC7799] provides clear definitions for active and passive
performance assessment such that the construction of metrics and performance assessment such that the construction of metrics and
methods can be described as either "Active" or "Passive". Even methods can be described as either "Active" or "Passive". Even
though [RFC7799] does not include the specific terms "Active", though [RFC7799] does not include the specific terms "Active",
"Passive", or "Hybrid" as modifiers of "OAM", the following terms are "Passive", or "Hybrid" as modifiers of "OAM", the following terms are
used in many RFCs and are provided here for use in all future IETF used in many RFCs and are provided here for use in all future IETF
documents that refer to OAM. documents that refer to OAM.
Active OAM: Active OAM:
Depends on dedicated, instrumented OAM packets. Depends on injected, dedicated OAM packets.
Passive OAM: Passive OAM:
Depends solely on the observation of one or more existing data Depends solely on the observation of one or more existing data
packet streams and does not use dedicated OAM packets. packet streams and does not use dedicated OAM packets.
Hybrid OAM: Hybrid OAM:
Uses instrumentation or modification of data packets themselves. Uses instrumentation or modification of data packets themselves.
[RFC9341] and [RFC9197] are examples labeled "Hybrid OAM" under [RFC9341] and [RFC9197] are examples labeled "Hybrid OAM" under
this definition. this definition.
Compound OAM: Compound OAM:
Uses a combination of at least two of Active OAM, Passive OAM, and Uses a combination of at least two of Active OAM, Passive OAM, and
Hybrid OAM (i.e., a combination of atomic OAM packets, data packet Hybrid OAM (i.e., a combination of atomic OAM packets, data packet
modification for OAM, and no explicit OAM). Note that [RFC7799] modification for OAM, and no explicit OAM). Note that Section 3.7
also uses the term "Hybrid" to refer to metric types in-between of [RFC7799] also uses the term "Hybrid" to refer to metric types
active and passive, for OAM there are no in-betweens per se, only in-between active and passive, for OAM there are no in-betweens
active, passive, hybrid, or a compound combination. per se, only active, passive, hybrid, or a compound combination.
Compound OAM can be characterized in a more explicit way, for Compound OAM can be characterized in a more explicit way, for
nuanced use-cases: nuanced use-cases, and named according to the OAM types that are
combined:
* Active-Passive OAM. * Active-Passive OAM.
* Active-Hybrid OAM. * Active-Hybrid OAM.
* Hybrid-Passive OAM. * Hybrid-Passive OAM.
* Active-Hybrid-Passive OAM. * Active-Hybrid-Passive OAM.
When two or more OAM types are combined, it is simply the case
that both OAM types are used at once. For example, in Active-
Passive OAM both specific OAM packets and the observation of data
packets may be used to provide information about the data flow in
the network. Each component may supplement the total data.
Note that [RFC7799] describes "passive methods" as "out of band" Note that [RFC7799] describes "passive methods" as "out of band"
which is contrary to the concept of "Passive OAM" as defined here which is contrary to the concept of "Passive OAM" as defined here
because there are no OAM packets to be in-band or out-of-band. because there are no OAM packets to be in-band or out-of-band.
Following the guidelines of this document, OAM may be qualified Following the guidelines of this document, OAM may be qualified
according to the terms described in Sections 2 and 3 of this according to the terms described in Sections 2 and 3 of this
document, and the term "out of band OAM" is not to be used in future document, and the term "out of band OAM" is not to be used in future
documents. documents.
